Article.ArticleTitle: Chloramines as an important photochemical source of chlorine atoms in the urban atmosphere.

AbstractText: Monochloramine, dichloramine and trichloramine (NH<sub>2</sub>Cl, NHCl<sub>2</sub>, NCl<sub>3</sub>) are measured in the ambient atmosphere, in downtown Toronto in summer (median 39, 15 and 2.8 ppt) and winter (median 11, 7.3 and 0.7 ppt). NCl<sub>3</sub> and NHCl<sub>2</sub> were also measured in summer (median 1.3 and 14 ppt) from a suburban Toronto location. Measurements at two locations demonstrate prevalence of chloramines in an urban atmosphere. At both sites, NCl<sub>3</sub> exhibits a strong diel pattern with maximum values during the night, and photolytic loss with sunrise. At the downtown site, a strong positive correlation between NH<sub>2</sub>Cl and NHCl<sub>2</sub> in the summer night indicates a common source, with daily average peak mixing ratios approaching 500 and 250 ppt, respectively. As a previously unidentified source of chlorine (Cl) atoms, we demonstrate that NCl<sub>3</sub> photolysis contributes 49 to 82% of the total local summertime Cl production rate at different times during the day with an average noontime peak of 3.8 × 10<sup>5</sup> atoms/cm<sup>3</sup>/s, with smaller contributions from ClNO<sub>2</sub> and Cl<sub>2</sub>. Photolysis of NH<sub>2</sub>Cl and NHCl<sub>2</sub> may augment this Cl production rate. Our measurements also demonstrate a daytime enhancement of chloroacetone in both the summer and winter, demonstrating the importance of Cl photochemistry. The results suggest that chloramines are an important source of Cl atoms in urban areas, with potential impacts on the abundance of organic compounds, ozone, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. Future studies should explore the vertical gradients of chloramines and their contribution to Cl production throughout the boundary layer.
